pulls.title: Initial version of CCF algorithm ID
pulls.author: ad-l

comments.author: ad-l
comments.body: Thanks for the reviews, I have addressed all the comments.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: @ad-l I don't see any reason not to merge.
very interested to discuss this, and specifically the interop issues, or how it will be used.

```suggestion
This document defines the `CCF-leaf` and `CCF-inclusion-proof` CBOR types. The signed Merkle Root data type `smtr` is the same as in {{-COMTRE}} but MUST set the protected header parameter carrying the identifier of the tree algorithm, `tree_alg`, to the value TBD_1.
```
This is indeed all you would need to register.. unless there are more "tree algorithm" specific proof types for CCF
Maybe highlight again where this CDDL fragment is used? At the moment this is a little bit free-floating, maybe?

```suggestion
  I-D.steele-cose-merkle-tree-proofs: COMTRE
```
Do we want to say ledger here? [CoMETRE](https://ietf-scitt.github.io/draft-steele-cose-merkle-tree-proofs/#go.draft-steele-cose-merkle-tree-proofs.html) does not use that term.

```suggestion
log tamper-proof.
```

```suggestion
The `internal_hash` and `internal_data` bytestrings are internal to the CCF implementation. Similarly, the auxiliary log entries are internal to CCF. They are opaque to receipt Verifiers, but they commit the TS to the whole log contents and may be used for additional, CCF-specific auditing.
```
Seems ok to call the algorithm a "ledger" here.

+1 to log

Okay... one more round. Tamper-Proof is such a strong word.. I am okay, but I would like to quickly float tamper-resilient or tamper-resistant. This is a non-blocking nit. Feel free to ignore
transitive +1
lgtm at this stage

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: okay to merge after all suggestions are accepted and remaining comments are acknowledged

comments.body: We are working on an internal proposal, maybe something to discuss at the next IETF?

@OR13 I would leave it as here but move the discussion to the latest COMETRE PR to see if we prefer to register multiple "tree algs" for different proof types or if we prefer to make "proof type" its own registry
Addressed in 8a40a20
Addressed both in 8a40a20. I also changed to tamper-resistant, I think I agree with your point
Fixed in 773fcbb

Thanks, this was actually an inconsistency, the type is mentioned first when recalling the `signed-inclusion-proof` type, but it called `CCF-inclusion-proof` there. I fixed the inconsistency in 085fdd8 and also added a mention about the element index not being present

pulls.title: Align with latest CoMeTre changes
pulls.author: ad-l
pulls.body: This uses the new proof type registry and redefines the signature type. Unlike the CT-style log algorithm the proof type is part of the trusted headers

comments.body:
I assume this is requesting a tag for the `proof type` for CCF?

See https://github.com/ietf-scitt/draft-steele-cose-merkle-tree-proofs/pull/18#issuecomment-1620457971

The current Cometre draft takes the 2 layer approach, you would encode a CCF inclusion proof using the TBD_2 tag of cometre... it would be understood as CCF proof, based on TBD_1 tag of cometer using your TBD_1 tag in this draft (you can request assignment of 2 for CCF).

```suggestion
* Identifier: TBD_1 (requested assignment 2)
```
we can iron out registration nits during the submission moratorium

pulls.title: Update draft and leaf details
pulls.author: achamayou
pulls.body:
@henkbirkholz @OR13 I have read through https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-cose-merkle-tree-proofs/, and made some edits here as discussed to correct the leaf definition.

This is deliberately quite light on details, but I am obviously very happy to expand wherever necessary.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: @ad-l I had not seen the updates made in https://github.com/ietf-scitt/draft-birkholz-cose-cometre-ccf-profile/pull/3, I have attempted to merge them in here.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: @henkbirkholz if/when you have a chance, I would be grateful for a review and some feedback on how to take this forward :)

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: @henkbirkholz I have tried to address your feedback, I hope I did not miss anything.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: @henkbirkholz may I ask you to check if the changes correctly addressed your feedback, and what the next steps are?

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: @henkbirkholz thank you for the discussion yesterday, I have [corrected the CDDL](https://github.com/ietf-scitt/draft-birkholz-cose-cometre-ccf-profile/pull/4/files#r1774895105) and added requested assignments for the labels. Please let me know if I need to do anything else before this can be merged.
CCF COSE Receipts?

```suggestion
title: A CoMETRE Profile for CCF COSE Receipts
```

This title was taken from #3, where it had received positive feedback. What I am suggesting in this comment is what feels most accurate to me, what do you think?

@OR13 I saw in #3 that you suggested adding references, which seems like an excellent idea. Do you have some pointers on the best way to add references in this kind of document? Just a link to the project's GitHub/paper?
Im not attached to any specific title, but I do prefer shorter titles, and I would avoid adding "CoMETRE" or "Merkle"... "CCF based COSE Receipts" or "COSE Receipts with CCF" seems sufficient.

Here is an example of how to add an arbitrary informative reference:

https://github.com/cose-wg/draft-ietf-cose-dilithium/pull/5/files#diff-2478aa1dfa824cbb11926553a0f4f8c9cd3e223126798f02e4827a8a56e809e9R62
Updated :) I was lulled into a longer title by the presence of the abbrev field, but I do agree that shorter is better here.

Maybe:
```suggestion
The COSE Receipts document {{-COMTRE}} defines a common framework for defining different types of proofs, such as proof of inclusion, about verifiable data structures (VDS). For instance, inclusion proofs guarantee to a verifier that a given serializable element is recorded at a given state of the VDS, while consistency proofs are used to establish that an inclusion proof is still consistent with the new state of the VDS at a later time.
```
Also, shouldn't I-D.steele-cose-merkle-tree-proofs (`{{-COMETRE}}`)be a normative reference?

```suggestion
```
Why newlines? For readability? Maybe appending the comments behind the array members combines readability and no newlines in the array definition.

labels/keys in arrays are intended to improve readability for humans and are not conveyed in the end. Was the intend maybe to use a map here, instead?

If so, is that also a possibility for other arrays that include elements with string label definitions (e.g., CCF-leaf that looks to me more like an annotation for humans that read the CDDL definition, but now I am not so sure)?

As all elements are mandatory, an array is an okay choice in any case. Just unsure about the intend of the labels.
If internal-transaction-hash and internal-evidence are not defined here, but are specified in CCF, maybe a reference to the definition is appropriate here?
Polishing the registration section is still a todo, but that does not have to be part of this PR.
Err... I-D.**IETF**-cose-merkle-tree-proofs I mean, of course :sweat_smile:
Sorry for asking a lot of dumb questions, but can you help me understand what's needed in that section, perhaps through a pointer to somewhere that does it right?
I adopted the style I found in https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-cose-hash-envelope/, but I am super happy to line up on what's generally preferred.

I think I prefer an array over a map here, repeating the keys seems quite wasteful considering this is not a self-describing document. I think I should have used comments here rather than labels, let me fix that.
I do not know to what extent it is ok to be specific, but I will add references.
Will fix
Sorry read that too quickly, a map does seem preferable at the top-level.
Reverted to something more compact.
Shall `data-hash` be explained below too?
done

```suggestion
  internal-evidence: tstr         ; a string of at most 1024 bytes
```

```suggestion
ccf-inclusion-proof = bstr .cbor {
```

Closer to draft 5 of https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-cose-merkle-tree-proofs/
To be validated and corrected as necessary
To be done in separate PR.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e6032ce8-fa08-401e-b1d1-feaf8e23d724)

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: :+1: let's pull this in and prepare for WG adoption call

pulls.title: Amend assignment requests
pulls.author: achamayou
pulls.body:
As discussed with @OR13 and @henkbirkholz, because the proof is scoped under `(unprotected) 396: -1`, when `(protected) 395 == 2 (requested assignment)`, and is ultimately wrapped in bstr to make parsing optional, there is no need to obtain assignments for keys it uses internally.

This PR is assigning values, and removing the requested assignments accordingly.

Edit: I've found that it's possible to be more precise about sizes in CDDL, so I've tightened the schema a bit.

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body: @henkbirkholz if you have a minute to have a look ahead of today's meeting, that'd be wonderful :)

comments.author: achamayou
comments.body:
@henkbirkholz CCF tests now automatically check some of the proofs against the schema: https://github.com/microsoft/CCF/pull/6520
Since this is approved, can it be merged?

comments.author: henkbirkholz
comments.body: @achamayou yes :-)

pulls.title: Specific VDS reg request
pulls.author: henkbirkholz
pulls.body: In alignment with draft-bryce-cose-merkle-mountain-range-proofs (i.e. this I-D will request VDS reg entry "2" and mmrp will request vds reg entry "3").

comments.body:
```suggestion
* Description: Append-only logs that are integrity-protected by
  a Merkle Tree and signatures produced via Trusted Execution
  Environments containing a mix of public and confidential information,
  as specified by the Confidential Consortium Framework.
```
Should fit in the line-length constraint of the formatter, I think.
